title: Grade 6 English Language Arts: A Foundation for Implementation
subject: English Language Arts

document.title: Grade 6 English Language Arts: A Foundation for Implementation

5D2FD175E42F4BABA50CDB880065D8AB.description: Evaluate Group Process - Assess own contributions to group process, set personal goals for enhancing work with others, monitor group process using checklists, and set group goals.

5BEE4E7682F44C689FE7C474A94B2E69.description: Use Language to Show Respect -   Demonstrate sensitivity to appropriate language use and tone when communicating orally.

D6EFB27EF66B42CBA37DD00AAEE1C8AE.description: Work in Groups - Select and assume roles to assist in the achievement of group goals; engage in on-going feedback.

FF9C532E5D2545349B7D8AD999F0EE70.description: Cooperate with Others - Assist group members to maintain focus and complete tasks; identify and solve group process issues.

DB83C64EF4BF40C58E0B528219FB2880.description: Encourage, Support, and Work with Others

EEA05021D4EE477E96CB5F10696D0A89.description: Celebrate Special Occasions - Explore and experiment with various ways in which language is used across cultures, age groups, and genders to honour and celebrate people and events.

5C2CF40660B540F2BEF9D85A95E99570.description: Appreciate Diversity - Observe and discuss aspects of human nature revealed in personal experiences and in oral, literary, and media texts; recognize personal participation and responsibility in communities.

B940E85743B141B7A616D4A5EDBDF7A9.description: Relate Texts to Culture - Incorporate language from oral, literary, and media texts to describe personal perspectives on cultural representations.

FAD694112EB649FABA7C2482BC7B2103.description: Compare Responses - Compare personal ways of responding and thinking with those of others.

1C138B6282D047CFBB8182982EC471DF.description: General Outcome 5: Students will listen, speak, read, write, view, and represent to celebrate and to build community.

DBCCD757720A43D9A79790D6CA111D66.description: Attentive Listening and Viewing -  Demonstrate critical listening and viewing skills and strategies [such as recognizing main idea and details, identifying inference...] and show respect for presenter(s) through appropriate audience behaviours [such as giving non-verbal encouragement, responding to emotional aspects of the presentation...].

9599F1BF707047A7AAF78BB217E3D71E.description: Effective Oral Communication - Use appropriate volume, phrasing, intonation, non-verbal cues [such as body language, facial expression...], and presentation space to enhance communication.

AFA4D77341B54C5F8EB24D6E0E4C9D03.description: Share Ideas and Information - Share information on a topic with class members in a planned and focused group session using a variety of strategies [such as interactive dialogues, demonstrations, dramatizations, audio-visual and artistic representations...].

78F8E0A44F574DECBB17CDD3FF5BAFBF.description: Punctuation and Capitalization -Know and apply capitalization and punctuation conventions in compound sentences, titles, headings, salutations, and addresses when editing and proofreading.

E0244AF22E574D999EEFF7A4582F00D1.description: Spelling (see Strategies) - Know and apply spelling conventions using appropriate strategies [including structural analysis, syllabication, and visual memory] and spelling patterns when editing and proofreading; use a variety of resources to determine the spelling of common exceptions to conventional spelling patterns.

C864D8B34A894E16A2A640CDEFA50FB4.description: Grammar and Usage  - Edit for subject-verb agreement, appropriate verb tense, and correct pronoun references.

DACA7F40879542B3889EDBC68D081820.description: Enhance Presentation - Prepare detailed and organized compositions, presentations, reports, and inquiry or research projects using templates or pre-established organizers.

DCD45177785A47A69EF4D8AFF98B21C9.description: Enhance Artistry - Choose language, sounds, and images [including transitional devices] to enhance meaning and emphasis.

13A9899B528F44F9943273200143F958.description: Enhance Legibility - Write legibly and at a pace appropriate to context and purpose when composing and revising; select and use a variety of formatting options [such as spacing, graphics, titles and headings, variety of font sizes and styles...] when appropriate.

B368911B2A35411B9B7BC9B28057A900.description: Revise Content -  Revise to eliminate unnecessary information.

DE796426FBE948B1BA4375E5AA039B4D.description: Appraise Own and Others’ Work - Share own stories and creations at appropriate times during revision and use criteria to provide feedback for others and to revise and assess own work and presentations.

1E04BA923CA549BCAABF1DC8024F3B7A.description: Organize Ideas -  Adapt models from listening, reading, and viewing experiences to enhance own oral, written, and visual texts using organizational patterns [such as stanzas, chronological order, paragraphs...].

8A57E912672A4FB0ADD4F115AAF5CCA6.description: Choose Forms -  Select specific forms [such as diaries, narratives, speeches, letters, poetry, mime...] that serve particular audiences and purposes.

47AF89CD3D4C4D7AABEA3D370CDA15B0.description: Generate Ideas - Focus a topic for oral, written, and visual texts integrating ideas from experiences and a variety of other sources.

372C11EC3912457CB2BC64C909293D4A.description: General Outcome 4: Students will listen, speak, read, write, view, and represent to enhance the clarity and artistry of communication.

382ED5A4AF34465E8CA40EF0D92B74AD.description: Develop New Understanding -  Relate gathered information to prior knowledge to reach conclusions or develop points of view; establish goals for developing further inquiry or research skills.

88C173E345A84B79B1DCD374BC096F2B.description: Evaluate Information - Evaluate the appropriateness of information for a particular form, audience, and purpose; identify gaps in information collected and gather additional information.

D4BED6C0E9AD4BABBAEA111E149C542E.description: Record Information - Make notes on a topic, combining information from more than one source; reference sources appropriately.

15F767284C9548DB81E3A51B4C615CDD.description: Organize Information -  Organize information and ideas using a variety of strategies and techniques [such as comparing and contrasting, classifying and sorting according to subtopics, sequences, order of priority or importance...].

8B001ECFA9B34A96BD76CCC2FEBFE061.description: Make Sense of Information - Use organizational patterns of oral, visual, and written texts [including main ideas and supporting details, explanation, comparison and contrast, cause and effect, and sequence] to construct meaning; skim, scan and read closely to gather information.

67C4B52CCD0D402EA99D05D5DDE628B6.description: Access Information - Use a variety of tools [including bibliographies, thesauri, and technology] to access information and ideas; use visual and auditory cues [such as captions, intonation, staging ...] to identify relevant information.

F4782939C2CB4777B551AEDCE4D7027A.description: Assess Sources - Recognize that information serves different purposes and determine its usefulness for inquiry or research focus using pre-established criteria.

BC0140BAD45A4B40A0C16AC89B9D17FF.description: Identify Sources -  Answer inquiry and research questions using a variety of information sources [such as bulletin boards, classroom displays art, music, skilled community people, CD-ROMs, Internet...].

77D2033B8851400A832C996E08C1EFF5.description: Identify Personal and Peer Knowledge -  Recall, record  and organize personal and peer knowledge of a topic for inquiry or research.

370C5960EE1B4244B747AA6E7147EACA.description: Create and Follow a Plan -  Create and follow a plan to collect and record information within a pre-established time frame.

39617C340AD84E519F7365569CC389A5.description: Contribute to Group Inquiry -  Contribute to group knowledge of topics to help identify and focus information needs, sources, and purposes for group inquiry or research.

E97204D8E5E24D5DB60FD406E98F68FE.description: Ask Questions - Formulate relevant questions to focus information needs for an inquiry.

1E0307DEA5C344A58670C17BB3C0AD23.description: Use Personal Knowledge - Summarize and focus personal knowledge of a topic to determine information needs.

16330D7F0E9C4F29AA04D05CD93E90D4.description: General Outcome 3: Students will listen, speak, read, write, view, and represent to manage ideas and information.

5E9C75FB55B64FB28FA109BA8DCE7DBF.description: Create Original Texts - Create original texts [such as letters, short stories, media broadcasts, plays, poems, video presentations, readers’ theater...] to communicate and demonstrate understanding of forms and techniques.

DE6373766CB14416A64BC29CA6FA6D4B.description: Experiment with Language - Alter words, forms, and sentence patterns to create new versions of texts for a variety of purposes [such as humour...]; explain ways in which figures of speech [such as similes, metaphors...] clarify and enhance meaning.

A7FBDB1AE96348918A01A57FC552EE71.description: Vocabulary - Experiment with ambiguity in language [such as puns, jokes based on multiple meanings, poetry...] in a variety of contexts.

59F21CA13BB84E56BD5EA2BEC513BCB6.description: Techniques and Elements -  Identify significant elements and techniques in oral, literary, and media texts, and examine how they interact to create effects.

78482362BA51403793852A06DDCA6EF0.description: Forms and Genre -  Recognize key characteristics of various forms and genres of oral, literary, and media texts [such as novels, biographies, autobiographies, myths, poetry, drawings, and prints...].

5B3435F8046F4E90A7E795D532FC58C4.description: Appreciate the Artistry of Texts -  Identify descriptive and figurative language in oral, literary, and media texts and discuss how it enhances understanding of people, places, and action.

DF7B688D437C41B9A4587A44C13C4F9B.description: Connect Self, Texts, and Culture - Discuss own and others’ understanding of various community and cultural traditions in various places and times as portrayed in oral, literary, and media texts [including texts about Canada or by Canadian writers].

D7D9631054DC47DBB97D290DC10FB070.description: Experience Various Texts - Seek opportunities to experience texts from a variety of forms and genres [such as autobiographies, travelogues, comics...] and cultural traditions; share responses.

F6810F6C7CD74535A26D785099D47C7D.description: Cueing Systems - Use syntactic, semantic, and graphophonic cueing systems [including word order, context clues; and multiple meanings of words, structural analysis to identify roots, prefixes, and suffixes] to construct and confirm meaning; use a dictionary to determine word meaning in context.

7F88ED391E374617841BDD6EC5DDC483.description: Textual Cues - Use textual cues [such as organizational structures of narrative and expository texts, headings, glossaries, margin notes...] to construct and confirm meaning.

E1B2B31329E44D18BFC7487835CF7098.description: Comprehension Strategies - Use comprehension strategies [such as asking questions, making notes, adjusting reading rate . . .] appropriate to the type of text and purpose [including summarizing, outlining, remembering ideas, and responding personally].

616E1E8AA5D1447699C9A57884031CFE.description: Prior Knowledge -  Seek connections between previous experiences, prior knowledge, and a variety of texts.

4243B8D0BAAD440CAC9119AC215F02B7.description: General Outcome 2: Students will listen, speak, read, write, view, and represent to comprehend and respond personally and critically to oral, literary, and media texts.

4548219150904DAEA3F736BAC52DB056.description: Extend Understanding -  Appraise ideas for clarity and ask extending questions; select from others’ experiences and ideas to extend ways of knowing the world.

15907CE9EC7B452DBBDFFF44CD560188.description: Combine Ideas -  Search for ways to reorganize ideas and information to extend understanding.

11B3645969A344A5BED36771986CCBF6.description: Explain Opinions -  Explain personal viewpoints in clear and meaningful ways and revise personal understanding.

09E9B08BFAED4B6DAC45A56A737E167A.description: Develop Understanding -  Reflect on prior knowledge and experiences to arrive at new understanding.

548C274ACDA04B2C8F9B9F93196A8BF9.description: Set Goals -  Assess personal language use and revise personal goals to enhance language learning and use.

EA469D1B91944E2391613267CD2E89B7.description: Express Preferences - Assess personal collection of favourite oral, literary, and media texts and discuss preferences for particular forms.

02110F514A624A1E8E903B7A93AE0490.description: Experiment with Language and Form - Experiment with new forms of self-expression.

AE04071A8D7E4A349BACFBAC57DAD502.description: Consider Others’ Ideas -   Select from others’ ideas and observations to develop thinking and understanding.

5B385D9373D54386A1DB1AB6905E77EC.description: Express Ideas - Engage in exploratory communication to share personal responses, make predictions, and discover own interpretations.

A46C79E2C39C48A7AECCC6247F64ADC3.description: General Outcome 1:  Students will listen, speak, read, write, view, and represent to explore thoughts, ideas, feelings, and experiences.
